intro: Ranunculus chrysopetalus, commonly known as the golden-rayed buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It features delicate, bright yellow petals surrounding a cluster of smaller, darker yellow petals, giving it a distinctive floral appearance. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10 to 30 centimeters, with trifoliate leaves that are finely divided. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes. The flowers bloom in early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
